Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Situation2: They occasionally offer comforting words to someone in their congregation who seems troubled.
Story:
I sat at my desk, headset snug against my ear, the script for our new service open in front of me. As a telemarketer, I was expected to handle customer objections and questions, but today, the calls were relentless. Each prospect seemed to have a dozen technical questions, most of which the script only half-answered. My supervisor’s voice echoed in my mind: “Stick to the script, don’t improvise.” But I could hear the frustration in the customers’ voices, and it gnawed at me.

Between calls, my phone buzzed with a message from a church member. She was struggling, her words heavy with worry. As her pastor, I was expected to provide spiritual guidance, to offer comfort and hope. My heart ached to call her, to listen and pray with her. But the next call blinked on my screen, another customer waiting, another barrage of questions I wasn’t supposed to answer fully.

I felt torn, pulled between the demands of my job and the needs of my congregation. The headset pressed into my temple, a physical reminder of the roles I was juggling, and I wondered how I could possibly meet the expectations of both.
